newsitem.title: UK: UK says music licensing problems being remedied.
newsitem.headline: UK says music licensing problems being remedied.

text.p: The British government said on Monday that the Performing Right Society (PRS) was making good progress in remedying a monopoly situation in the licensing of copyright music.

The PRS, a non-profit making organisation set up more than 80 years ago to licence music for broadcast and gather royalities, found itself the subject of a Monopolies and Mergers Commission (MMC) inquiry last year.
It has since amended its articles to allow members to administer their own live performing rights.

"I asked the Director General of Fair Trading to ensure that the PRS implemented the 44 recommendations made by the MMC, and he has reported to me good progress by them towards fulfilling most of the recommendations," Consumer Affairs Minister John Taylor said in a statement.
The PRS represents about 30,000 composers, songwriters and music publishers in Britain.
